content:
Sea Urchin Egg Morphology 
Shed eggs from good ripe females are generally ready for fertilization. Both
maturation divisions have occurred in the ovary and the polar bodies are generally lost.
Lytechinus variegatus is unusual. In this form, the polar bodies regularly remain
attached to the egg surface. Egg suspensions from some females may contain immature
eggs. These are easily recognized by their large primary oocyte nuclei (germinal
vesicle). Strongylocentrotus purpuratus eggs are approximately 80 microns in diameter.
They are surrounded by a jelly coat, made of large sulfated glycoproteins, which has the
same refractive index as water and therefore is invisible. With their jelly coats intact,
the eggs form a regular lattice work in a monolayer.
Insemination
Best results are obtained with good fresh eggs and sperm. Such material under
proper conditions should give nearly 10096 fertilized eggs. Filter egg suspension through
several layers of gauze or cheesecloth. Wash eggs at least once in MFSW just before
fertilizing them by letting them settle and aspirating off the FSW, replacing it with fresh
MFSW. "Dry" sperm should be diluted in FSW just before insemination. Sperm
concentration should be kept low to reduce chances of polyspermy. Excess sperm will
also contribute to contamination of cultures. Dilute about one of sperm in 20 ml
MFSW and add to about 250 ml of egg suspension containing ~lO eggs (10 ml packed
eggs). Fertilized eggs, identified by their elevated fertilization membranes, should be
washed several times by repeated settling and aspiration, as above, to remove excess
sperm.
Embryonic and Larval Cultures
Embryonic and larval stages should be maintained in FSW with regular changes.
Excess sperm, immature eggs, egg fragments, and unfertilized eggs will support bacterial
growth and subsequent ciliate contamination of cultures. In cases where immature or
unfertilized material is present in quantity, healthy embryos can be separated by gently
decanting the culture into a partially immersed chamber whose bottom is formed by
Nitex screen of a mesh size small enough to retain the embryos but large enough to
permit the eggs and egg fragments to pass through. Gentle agitation of the chamber will
concentrate the embryos without excessive damage. They can then be washed with sea
Water.
Bacterial contamination can be more rigorously reduced in early embryonic
cultures by the addition of penicillin (20 u/liter) and streptomycin (50 ug/liter)
Penicillin/streptomycin stock 'solutions may be made up at l000X concentrates in MFSW
and frpzen in small aliquots at Embryonic cultures should not exceed
/liter FSW (l-296 by volume) and should be provided with a continuously stirring
mechanism a motor-driven paddle working at -30-60 RPM). The stirring keeps the
embryos from accumulating on the bottom or at the surface film and the culture
develops more evenly. Large cultures should be provided with an air source an air
stone or compressed air). As the embryos grow and begin to feed, cultures should be kept
more dilute and the MFSW (without antibiotics, which are detrimental to food sources)
changed more frequently. Larval rearing will not be addressed here.
Collecting Embryos and Larvae from Cultures
Eggs and embryos can be collected by settling or gentle centrifugation. Once
concentrated, they should be immediately resuspended or prepared for experimental
